article_title: Arkansas Lawmakers Pass 'Private Option' Health-Care Law
article_text:
Arkansas lawmakers voted Tuesday to continue allowing the state to use Medicaid dollars to buy private health-care insurance for poorer residents, overcoming resistance from some Republicans who said the program amounted to an endorsement of the Affordable Care Act.

Arkansas last fall became the first state to offer a "private option" to extend coverage to lower-income residents, the result of a compromise between state Republicans and Democrats over how to implement a crucial provision of the health law. The...

og.description: The state's House of Representatives votes to continue a program that allows Arkansas to use Medicaid dollars to buy private health-care insurance for poorer residents.
og.title: Arkansas Lawmakers Pass 'Private Option' Health-Care Law

article_metadata.author: Ana Campoy and Louise Radnofsky
article_metadata.article.origheadline: Arkansas Lawmakers Pass ‘Private Option’ Health-Care Law

article_summary:
Arkansas last fall became the first state to offer a "private option" to extend coverage to lower-income residents, the result of a compromise between state Republicans and Democrats over how to implement a crucial provision of the health law.
Arkansas lawmakers voted Tuesday to continue allowing the state to use Medicaid dollars to buy private health-care insurance for poorer residents, overcoming resistance from some Republicans who said the program amounted to an endorsement of the Affordable Care Act.
